WHAT IS CANNING? Canning is a way to keep food fresh for a long time in jars by heating them to high temperatures for a long time. This kills microorganisms and stops enzymes that cause food to go wrong. As the food cools, the air is pushed out of the jar by heating, making a vacuum seal.

HOW DOES CANNING WORK? When you heat up filled and sealed jars, the food inside expands and gives of f steam, which pushes air out of the jars. When it cools, it makes a seal on the jar that keeps air out. The amount of sugar and acidity can af fect canning and the food's shelf life. When you're just starting, it's best to follow a canning recipe to figure out which method is best for the food you'll be canning.

2 HOME CANNING METHODS 1. Water bath canning. This method is a way to can food at a lower temperature. It works well for acidic foods and recipes that use the right amount of acid. It is suitable for fruits, jams, jellies, salsa, tomatoes, pickles, chutneys, sauces, pie fillings, and condiments. 2. Pressure canning. Low-acid foods need to be kept safe by using this high-temperature method. It's suitable for meats, poultry , vegetables, chili, and seafood. The USDA says you shouldn't can with a pressure cooker because there are too many dif ferent kinds with dif ferent results.

WHAT DO YOU NEED TO CAN AT HOME? 1. Jar lifter T ongs: Tongs help pick up hot jars and take them out of hot water safely after they have been processed. 2. Ladle: You can put food in canning jars using a spoon. 3. Wide-mouth funnel : A wide-mouth funnel has a bigger opening to fit into jars. It makes filling your jars easier and keeps the rims clean. 4 . Canning jars and seals: Use Mason jars with tight-fitting lids. It is suggested to use Ball mason jars. 5. Large pot or water-bath canner: If you want to make primarily fruits, jams, jellies, pickles, and salsa, a water-bath canner or a large pot will work well.
WHAT CAN YOU CAN? 1. Fruits 2. Tomatoes 3. Vegetables 4. Meat, poultry , and seafood 5. Jams and jellies 6. Pickles and fermented vegetables

TIPS FOR GETTING THE MOST OUT OF HOMEMADE CANNING 1. Use only fresh food. Can your fruits and vegetables when they are at their best. A void any that are damaged or too ripe. 2. A canner with boiling water or one with pressure? A boiling water bath can be used to store acidic foods like pickles, jams, and tomatoes. But foods that aren't acidic, like soup stocks, vegetables that haven't been pickled, and meat, must be canned in a pressure canner . 3. Put the food in the jars while they're still hot. Pack hot food into jars one at a time, leaving enough space at the top to seal them. Once it's complete, put it back in the water that's just about to boil. 4. Listen for popping sounds. Once the jar is sealed correctly , you should hear a "pop," and the lid shouldn't pop up. 5. Overfilling jars. A good recipe will tell you to leave some room between the top of the food and the edge of the jar . The lids won't seal properly if you put too much in the jars. Unsealed jars don't mean the end of the world. Y ou can put them in the fridge and use them within a few days or reprocess them with enough head space to seal.

WHAT IS THE SHELF LIFE OF CANNED GOODS? Generally , home-canned foods that haven't been opened and are kept in a cool, dry place can last for a year . Homemade jams made with sugar and put through a hot water bath canning process will last about two years. Follow canning recipes to make sure food is safe.

HOW DO YOU KNOW IF CANNED GOODS HAVE GONE BAD? Even though most canned food can be stored for a long time, look for these signs that the food inside the can has gone wrong: 1. If the seal is broken, air can get in. A lid that bulges can also be a sign that something is terrible. 2. A lid that has rust or corrosion on it 3. Bubbles when the can is opened 4. Food that looks cloudy or has grown mold 5. Food that has a bad smell when the jar is opened

STEP-BY-STEP GUIDE: BASIC WATER BATH CANNING 1. Wash canning jars in hot water with soap, then rinse. Put clean jars in a canner with a water bath or in another deep, large pot. Cover with hot water from the tap, and let it cook for 10 minutes over medium heat. Keep them in simmering hot water until you are ready to use them. Pour hot water from the sterilizing pot over the lids in a bowl. When ready , take one clean jar out of the water and set it on a clean kitchen towel. 2. Use a ladle and funnel to put food in the jar . Leave a headspace of 14 inches at the top. 3. Poke the food with a clean chopstick or wooden skewer to release any trapped air bubbles. 4. Wipe the rims of the jars with a clean, damp cloth, and screw on the lids. 5. Use a jar lifter to gently put each jar in the canner after you've filled and sealed it. 6. Make sure the jars don't touch each other . As you add jars to the pot, you may need to drain some water . 7. Put all the jars inside and cover them with an inch of water . 8. Put the lid on the canner and bring the water to a full boil. 9. Boil jars for 10 minutes (length of processing time may vary from recipe to recipe). T ake the jars out and set them on a towel-covered counter to cool down to room temperature. The jars should ping as soon as they are taken out of the pot. The sound comes from the seals being made. As the vacuum seal takes hold, the center of the lids will go down, creating an airtight seal.

10. When the jars have cooled down, test the seals by pressing the middle of the lids. The pot isn't sealed if the top pops up and down. Jars that don't seal can be kept in the fridge and used within three days or processed within 24 hours. 11.
